nodes.text: Introducing government debt into a neoclassical overlapping-generations growth model affects long-run competitive equilibrium; specifically, external and internal government debt change equilibrium interest rates, capital stocks, and individual lifetime utility

Method: Model is an infinite-horizon overlapping-generations economy with two-period-lived individuals, discrete time, constant-returns aggregate production function F(K,L)=L f(k), no depreciation, lump-sum taxes on young, and government debt expressed as debt-labor ratios

Assumption: Government debt is one-period maturity and the debt-labor ratio is held constant (debt grows at population growth rate n), with interest on debt paid at current domestic rate for internal and external debt in the main text

Claim: The competitive equilibrium may be dynamically inefficient (capital-labor ratio exceeding Golden Rule) so the direction of welfare effects of debt depends on whether the equilibrium interest rate r is greater or less than population growth n

Claim: External debt affects the domestic economy only through taxes needed to finance interest payments and by shifting the savings-schedule derived function i1(w) because taxes reduce disposable wage and savings

Claim: Internal debt has both the tax effect (reducing disposable income and savings) and an additional portfolio substitution effect that replaces physical capital with government debt in private portfolios, further reducing the capital stock and output

Method / Equilibrium condition: Capital market equilibrium equates aggregate desired saving S(w,r) to capital demanded K_{t+1}; long-run equilibria satisfy r = f'(s(w - (r-n)g, r)/(1+n)) where g denotes debt-labor ratios

Result / Mechanism: Taxes to finance interest payments reduce lifetime disposable consumption and reduce savings which lowers the capital-labor ratio k and shifts the i1 curve (relation between current wage and next-period interest) leading to higher equilibrium interest rate when supply is reduced

Result: Implicit differentiation of the equilibrium condition shows the sign of dr/dg (change in equilibrium interest rate with respect to debt-labor ratio) has same sign as (r - n); thus debt moves r away from n in the canonical case treated in text

Claim: Welfare effect sign depends on efficiency case: when competitive solution is efficient (r > n) additional debt (external or internal) lowers lifetime utility of individuals in long-run equilibrium; when inefficient (r < n) effects may reverse

Evidence: Diagrammatic and algebraic analysis decomposes utility change dU/dg into three components — (i) tax cost for new debt, (ii) tax cost on existing debt due to r change, and (iii) change in factor payments from movement of r — and shows components have signs determined by (r - n) and dr/dg

Result: Internal debt substitution (issuing internal debt to retire external debt) raises the domestic interest rate (government increases demand for loanable funds), lowers capital-labor ratio, and in the efficient case unambiguously lowers utility; in inefficient case effect ambiguous

Claim / Comparative: External debt and internal debt share identical tax effects on individuals; internal debt adds a demand-side portfolio substitution effect that amplifies the negative welfare impact in the efficient case relative to external debt

Limitation: Alternative assumptions about slopes of supply and demand in capital market or alternative external capital supply (appendices) can reverse sign patterns (e.g., if supply curve elasticity is large negative or external supply horizontal), so some comparative results are model-dependent

Conclusion: In the standard case with stable competitive equilibrium and r > n, both external and internal debt reduce long-run individual utility, with internal debt typically producing a larger decline; if r < n (dynamic inefficiency) debt can increase utility and signs are ambiguous
